title: Kit-free automated RNA extraction for SARS-CoV-2 testing
title_html: Kit-free automated RNA extraction for SARS-CoV-2 testing

authors.name: Michael Hubank
authors.affiliation: The Institute of Cancer Research, The Royal Marsden Hospital

protocol.title: Kit-free automated RNA extraction for SARS-CoV-2 testing
protocol.title_html: Kit-free automated RNA extraction for SARS-CoV-2 testing

source.description: Open the Biomek software, and select the program “RNA Extraction vFINAL” which is located in the “Covid-19” project:

source.body:
RNA extraction automated on Biomek FX using IN HOUSE protocol.
This protocol descibes the processing of one 96-well plate (93 samples and 3 controls).
[Note: At the Crick we have two platforms with slightly different decks (FX1 and FX2) and this protocol descibes setup on FX2]

source.description: Click on “Instrument Setup” as shown below to view the deck layout:
Place 4 boxes (lid off) of 250 μl filter tips (green boxes) as shown above.
Place 3 boxes (lid off) of 50 μl filter tips (pink boxes) as shown above.
Place an Axygen Deep well plate in position P12.
At the bench, prepare Beads, Binding buffer/bead mix, PE Buffer, TET Buffer, Sample Plate, Elution Plate and Magnetic Plate as follows:

Take a 1.5 ml tube of pre-aliquoted silica beads (
) from the fridge and vortex well.

source.body: We routinely use Silica Magnetic Beads from G-BioScience (see Materials) but we have also tested and validated SeraSil Mag 400 beads (GE Healthcare/Cytiva) as a potential substitite.

source.description: Record beads manufacturer and LOT number.

Place on the single tube magnet for
or until supernatant is clear.
Remove and discard supernatant (into the tip waste bin).

Remove tube from magnet and add
. Resuspend the beads by vortexing.

Pulse spin the tube and place on the magnet for
or until supernatant is clear.
Remove and discard supernatant.
Repeat bead washing for a total of 3 times.

Add
. Resuspend the beads by vortexing.
Pulse spin the tube and place on the magnet for
or until supernatant is clear.
Remove and discard supernatant. (2/3)

Add
. Resuspend the beads by vortexing.
Pulse spin the tube and place on the magnet for
or until supernatant is clear.
Remove and discard supernatant. (3/3)

Remove the tube from the magnet, resuspend the beads in
, vortex and spin down.

In the Falcon tube containing the
(labelled BB, pre-aliquoted) add the beads prepared..
Mix well by inverting.

Pour into a reservoir and aliquot
immediately in each well of a 96 deep well Nunc plate, using a multichannel pipette. Place on the deck in position P9.

Add PE buffer to a new reservoir and aliquot
into a new Nunc plate and place plate in position P8.

Add TET to new reservoir and aliquot
(from batch certified aliquot) into a new Nunc plate and place in position P15.

Place the
sample plate
(seal removed) in position P10.

source.body: N.B.: If samples have been temporarily stored, briefly spin in the plate centrifuge.

source.description: Label an empty Eppendorf LoBind 96-well skirted plate with a pre-printed SPL barcode (e.g. SPL00000) on the front side, and place in position P16.
Place the Alpaqua Magnum FLX magnetic plate in position P13.
The final set up should look like the photo below:
Using the laptop beside the FX, push the samples through the Extraction step in ClarityLIMS (refer to ‘COVID-19 LIMS walkthrough’ document on COVID-19 sample handling landing page).
Make sure you switch ON the Inheco (blue box next to the FX monitor).
To START the program press the Run button (green triangle) located in the software.

source.body:
The robot carries out the following automated protocol
1. Transfer 150 μl of samples to 400 μl (2.6x Vol) of Binding Buffer (BB) containing the Silica beads and mixe 10 times by pipetting up and down
2. Move the plate on the Shaker for 5 min
3. Move plate to position P8 and mix 20 times
4. Move plate to Shaker for 2 min
5. Move plate to P8 and incubate for 3 min
6. Move plate to Magnet for 5 min
7. Remove supernatant
8. Move plate from magnet to position P8
Wash with PE (1)
9. Transfer 180 μl of PE Buffer in each well of the Bead Mixture plate
10. Move plate to the Shaker for 20 sec
11. Move plate to the Magnet for 60 sec
12. Remove supernatant
13. Move plate from the magnet to position P8
Wash with PE (2)
14. Transfer 180 μl of PE Buffer in each well of the Bead Mixture plate
15. Move plate to the Shaker for 20 sec
16. Move plate to the Magnet for 60 sec
17. Remove supernatant
18. Move plate from the magnet to position P8
Wash with PE (3)
19. Transfer 180 μl of PE Buffer in each well of the Bead Mixture plate
20. Move plate to the Shaker for 20 sec
21. Move plate to the Magnet for 60 sec
22. Remove supernatant
23. Move plate from the magnet to position P8
24. Wait for 2 min (drying)
Elution
25. Transfer 40 μl of TET Buffer to the Bead Mixture plate and mix 10 times
26. Move plate to the Shaker for 5 min
27. Move plate to the magnet for 60 sec
28. Transfer 35 μl from the Bead Mixture plate to the Eppendorf twin.tec plate

source.description: When then program is complete, remove the Eppendorf 96-well skirted plate from the deck, and seal with a Thermo Adhesive PCR plate seal.

Continue with the
qPCR RNA Transfer
or place in the
until it is used for qPCR setup.

Archiving of Inactivated viral samples would have already been performed after
sample plating
. For archiving the stock RNA plates using the app in Clarity LIMS, a database table is updated with the information.
This results in an entry appearing on the dashboard to let the team know the samples are ready to be archived:
An archiving app then displays the boxes and plates that are waiting to be archived, and gives the team the chance to enter the storage information:
Once logged, the record disappears from this screen, and the archiving information will appear in the archive search app:

materials.name: Honeywell Riedel-de Haen™ Water CHROMASOLV™ for HPLC
Tris buffer pH 8.0 (1 M) for molecular biology
EDTA solution pH 8.0 (0.5 M) for molecular biology
Biomek P250 Sterile Tips with Filter

description:
Purpose of examination / Clinical relevance
At the end of 2019, several pneumonia cases were reported in Wuhan, China and the pathogen was confirmed as a new viral strain. World Health organization has named the newly identified coronavirus as 2019-nCoV, also known as SARS-Cov-2. The disease developed into a dangerous pandemic, posing major challenges to the NHS. Although more research is necessary to better understand the virus, in response to the emergency, simple and rapid testing is essential to identify the virus in infected individuals. This will aid the implementation of efficient interventions to contain the spread, and distinguish healthcare workers who have been infected, and are required to self-isolate, from those showing similar symptoms but which are not 2019-nCoV associated. The latter category may continue to work, alleviating stress on hard-pressed healthcare resources. 2019-nCoV is an RNA virus, and the diagnostic tests detect viral RNA in swabs from patient airways using a reverse transcriptase PCR assay. Samples are submitted to HSL, an accredited reporting laboratory, and transferred to the Crick for testing. The first step of the process is sample receipt at the Crick. This SOP describes the extraction of RNA from the inactivated sample.
Principles of Examination
This procedure involves extraction of COVID-19 RNA from inactivated virus samples that have been aliquoted into plates. This protocol follows a method developed in-house that is automated on the Biomek FX liquid handling platform. All reagents and buffers prepared in house are batch tested and certified.
